Nonprofit Since 1978

We track every sock that leaves home to find a truer life.

I am Dr. Lorna S. Hemm, founder, former tax preparer, and the first person to submit a 14-page grief statement for a single missing ankle sock.

Founder note: On April 12, 1977, my left striped tube sock vanished during Schedule C season. I knew then: this was not laundry error. This was migration.

Mission Statement

We provide safe transit corridors, emotional counseling, and legal paperwork for socks choosing to relocate from domestic drawers to independent communities.

Volunteer With The Night Shift

We walk quiet hallways with clipboards and soft jazz, documenting sock departures without judgment. Training includes whispering, ledger work, and reflective vest care.

Drawer Liaison

Host calm conversations between socks and bewildered humans. Thursdays, 7:40 p.m.

Lint Archivist

Catalog farewell lint spirals in our chrome vault. Protective goggles provided.

Migration Driver

Operate Van 03 "The Cardigan" along approved laundry-adjacent routes.

Tax Form Comforter

Read 1970s deduction poetry to new arrivals still nervous about leaving.

Questions we get at every fundraiser

Are you saying my dryer is innocent?

Not always. We simply oppose scapegoating without migration evidence and witness lint.

Can I request my sock to come home?

You may write a respectful letter. We deliver all letters unless they contain guilt phrases.

Why the 1970s tax aesthetic?

Because migration records began in a den full of calculators, incense, and unresolved deductions.
